member.name: P:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.ClassHandle
member.summary: The Objective-C class handle for this class.
member.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
member.remarks: Each managed class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class. It is similar to calling the managed or the native objc_getClass method with the type name.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new with default values.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.#ctor(Foundation.NSObjectFlag)
member.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the . This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke this constructor, they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using this constructor chain.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the corresponding base implementation, then it should also call an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.#ctor(ObjCRuntime.NativeHandle)
member.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects. Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call as it will prevent two instances of a managed object pointing to the same native object.
This class contains various helper methods that allow developers to observe events posted in the notification hub ().
The methods defined in this class post events that invoke the provided method or lambda with a parameter, which contains strongly typed properties for the notification arguments.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.Notifications.ObserveA(System.EventHandler{Foundation.NSNotificationEventArgs})
member.summary: Strongly typed notification for the constant.
member.param: The handler that responds to the notification when it occurs.
member.returns: Token object that can be used to stop receiving notifications by either disposing it or passing it to .

remarks.para: This method can be used to subscribe to notifications.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.Notification1.Notifications.ObserveA(Foundation.NSObject,System.EventHandler{Foundation.NSNotificationEventArgs})
member.summary: Strongly typed notification for the constant.
member.param: The handler that responds to the notification when it occurs.
member.returns: Token object that can be used to stop receiving notifications by either disposing it or passing it to .

remarks.para: This method can be used to subscribe to notifications.

member.name: T:XmlDocumentation.P1_Extensions
member.summary: Extension methods to the interface to support all the methods from the P1 protocol.

remarks.para: The extension methods for interface allow developers to treat instances of the interface as having all the optional methods of the original P1 protocol. Since the interface only contains the required members, these extension methods allow developers to call the optional members of the protocol.

member.name: T:XmlDocumentation.TypeWithApparance.TypeWithApparanceAppearance
member.summary: Appearance class for objects of type .

remarks.para: This appearance class is a strongly typed subclass of UIAppearance that is intended to be used with objects of class .
You can obtain an instance to this class by either accessing the static property or by calling to get a UIAppearance that is context sensitive.

member.name: P:XmlDocumentation.TypeWithApparance.Appearance
member.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of .
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of , they should use the method.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.TypeWithApparance.GetAppearance``1
member.summary: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of .
member.typeparam: The type for which the proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of .

returns.para: An appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by this method can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how this method works:
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

member.name: M:XmlDocumentation.TypeWithApparance.AppearanceWhenContainedIn(System.Type[])
member.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
member.summary: Returns a strongly typed for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
member.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of , they should use the method.
The following example shows how this method works:

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

returns.para: An appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The following example shows how this method works:
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of , they should use the method.
For more information, see the documentation for the class.
